name: 3-methylphenoxyacetic acid
Reason: To predict the melting point of 3-methylphenoxyacetic acid, we consider the effect of each functional group relative to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The compound contains a benzene ring, a phenol ether functional group (-O-), a methyl group (-CH3), and a carboxylic acid group (-COOH). The phenol ether linkage tends to slightly increase the melting point by enhancing the molecular weight and providing moderate polarity, and we estimate this increment to be around +25 degrees Celsius. The methyl group adds steric bulk and slightly increases molecular weight but is not expected to have a strong influence on the melting point due to its nonpolar character; it might contribute around +5 degrees Celsius. The carboxylic acid group contributes significantly to the melting point due to its capacity to form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds. This functional group could increase the melting point by approximately +70 degrees Celsius. Combining these adjustments, we arrive at an estimated melting point for 3-methylphenoxyacetic acid.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. The introduction of a methoxy group (–OCH3) generally increases the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and the possibility of additional dipole-dipole interactions. This effect can be estimated at around +10°C. The carboxylic acid group (–COOH) is known to significantly increase the melting point due to strong hydrogen bonding and dimerization. This effect can be estimated at around +80°C. The presence of the methyl group (–CH3) is expected to have a minor effect on the melting point, possibly increasing it by around +5°C due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions.
